message:
KSHITIJ
Technology Robotix Society conducted 3 events in Kshitij.
Zenith, the manual event, Cubiscan, the autonomous event, and Crusade, the image processing event. The participants from all across the country worked feverishly for 3 days, making their bots run in the arena and winning cash prizes and certificates! The events faced a lot of challenges which were cleverly overcome by the enthusiastic participants. The event was held successfully and was an amazing end to the year 2018-19.
#RobotixRecap

WINTER WORKSHOP
As a necessity to obtain enough knowledge to get into research groups, the winter workshops were excellently conducted by the society in collaboration with the research groups and also saw a lot of participation. The syllabus was interesting and also challenging, after which a problem statement was also solved and bots were built.
The 2 workshops, on embedded systems and image processing, were a fun learning experience!

#RobotixRecap
story: Technology Robotix Society is with Shivansh Sethi and Sumegh Roychowdhury.

Technology Robotix Society shared a post. KRAIG SESSIONS The basics of bot making necessary for the robosoccer events such as, drive mechanisms, different switches, etc. were taught.There were exhaustive workshops on advanced manual robotics like arm, forklift, shooting, stair climbing mechanisms. We also introduced freshers to the world of autonomous robotics with examples like line following, lane follower,etc. All in all, the KRAIG sessions were incredibly successful in providing a kickstart into robotics! LINE FOLLOWER HACKATHON The first chance for the freshers to try their hand at making a line follower bot was met with enthusiasm and teams worked feverishly throughout the night to build their bots. It was a golden opportunity to learn to make bots on one's own! #robotix_recap
story: Technology Robotix Society shared a post.

message:
KRAIG SESSIONS
The basics of bot-making necessary for the robosoccer event such as drive mechanisms, different switches, controller circuit designing etc. were taught. There were exhaustive workshops on advanced manual robotics like arm, forklift, shooting, stair climbing and other mechanisms. We also introduced freshers to the world of autonomous robotics with examples of line following and lane following bots.
All in all, the KRAIG sessions were incredibly successful in providing a kickstart into robotics!

LINE FOLLOWER HACKATHON
The first chance for the freshers to try their hand at making a line follower bot was met with enthusiasm and teams worked feverishly throughout the night to build their bots. It was a golden opportunity to learn to make bots on one's own!
#robotix_recap

Hey fellow robotics enthusiasts!
It's been a wonderful, hectic, eventful journey as well as a huge learning experience for all of us this year 2018-2019.
Let's take a quick revisit through the year right from the induction program up until the fest Kshitij.

INDUCTION PROGRAM
As the very first interaction with the incoming fresher's batch, the induction program saw a lot of participation and enthusiasm to learn the basics needed to make their very own bots.
The participants took away useful knowledge which they later used for other Robotix events, along with a fun-filled time!

INTRO SEMINAR
The intro seminar, meant to educate the freshers about the kind of technical and managerial work that Technology Robotix Society does and to give an insight into the culture of robotics here at IIT KGP, was conducted and received a great response from the freshers who were very excited to get a chance to handle the bots themselves.

#robotix_recap
story: Technology Robotix Society is with Vamsi Krishna and Saswata Banerjee.

Technology Robotix Society shared a post. Calling in first and second-year students! The registration link for selections is: http://swarm-iitkgp.github.io/recruit Swarm Robotics will recruit members for its software team, through a contest. Please follow this link for further details: https://github.com/Swarm-IITKgp/SwarmSoftwareSelections The selections for the embedded and the mechanical team will be held on coming Tuesday and Wednesday (5th and 6th Feb), from 6pm onwards at Swarm Lab (Upper Lab, Gymkhana). See you there!

Anirudh Roy shared a post to Technology Robotix Society's timeline. Imagine designing a robot capable of crossing gaps as well as changing its ground clearance to elude obstacles. The mechanical event in Robotix 2019, Zenith will give you that opportunity. This is your chance to create a paper design for the event. If your design wins, you'll get a direct entry into the second round of the event at Robotix 2019, where a lot of exciting prizes await you. To read more about Zenith visit https://www.robotix.in/event/zenith/ The final date for submissions is 30th December, 2018.

Hey everyone,
1. The second phase of the winter workshop begins on 8th December.

2. Those who did not register for the workshop must report at 12 noon in F-235, Main Building.

3. Those who have registered for the workshop must report at 2 pm in the slots and venue in the main building mentioned below:

Autonomous:
a. Group 1: F-234

Image Processing:
Group 1, 2, 3: F-244

4. Those who are participating in the image processing workshop should carry a pen drive and try to dual boot their laptop with Ubuntu and install OpenCV before coming for the workshop.

4. If your name is on the list and you haven’t registered, you won’t be allowed to attend the workshop. So it’s mandatory for everyone to register.

5. If someone has any other issue with the registration or anything else, please report to us at 12 noon in F-235, Main Building to get the problem resolved.

6. Make sure you bring your laptops to the workshop.

Autonomous:
a. Group 1: F-232
b. Group 2: F-233
c. Group 3: F-234

Image Processing:
Group 1, 2, 3:  F-244

4. If your name is on the list and you haven’t registered, you won’t be allowed to attend the workshop. So it’s mandatory for everyone to register.
  
5. If someone has any other issue with the registration or anything else, please report to us at 12 noon in F-235, Main Building to get the problem resolved.

6. Make sure you bring your laptops to the workshop.

Anirudh Roy shared a post to Technology Robotix Society's timeline. Team Robotix, IIT Kharagpur is expanding. @Robotics’ Enthusiasts all across the country: Join us today! Technology Robotix Society announces the selection for the post of Robotix Student Executives (RSE) in technical colleges all over India. RSEs will be our point of contact with the particular college and will aid communication and interaction to encourage robotics activities there. All RSEs receive a certificate from Team Robotix, as well as exclusive Robotix merchandise, certification from Technology Robotix Society, constant contact with robotics experts for any kind of help and advice on robotics, and the tag itself. If you are passionate about robotics and want your college to shine at Robotix 2019, all that you have to do is fill up an online form. Click: www.robotix.in/rse/ to be one of the Robotix Student Executives. The deadline for the application is 1st December ,23:59 hrs.

Team Robotix, IIT Kharagpur is expanding. @Robotics’ Enthusiasts all across the country: Join us today! Technology Robotix Society announces the selection for the post of Robotix Student Executives (RSE) in technical colleges all over India.
RSEs will be our point of contact with the particular college and will aid communication and interaction to encourage robotics activities there. All RSEs receive a certificate from Team Robotix, as well as exclusive Robotix merchandise, certification from Technology Robotix Society, constant contact with robotics experts for any kind of help and advice on robotics, and the tag itself.
If you are passionate about robotics and want your college to shine at Robotix 2019, all that you have to do is fill up an online form.

Click: www.robotix.in/rse/ to be one of the Robotix Student Executives.
The deadline for the application is 1st December ,23:59 hrs.

Hey everyone! 
Due to an overwhelming response to the winter workshop test and persistent requests from many, we are conducting a compensatory test for the same. The first years who have not taken the test yesterday should come outside Kalidas Auditorium at 6 pm sharp today, i.e. 30/10/2018. You must bring your laptops for taking the test. In case a first year does not have a laptop, we will provide one. Those first years who have registered but not received the email for the test can come to the above venue.

The second years who could not take the test yesterday can come to F-236, main building at 6:30 pm sharp. Again, those who registered for the test and did not receive the email can also come.

Note that this is the final call for the students interested in the winter workshop. After this, no more requests shall be entertained.

The Winter Workshop test for the first years will begin from 6:15 pm onwards at CIC lab, while for the second years it will commence at 9:00 pm today in F-244 main building, i.e. on 29th October. The test shall be of 45 minutes. The registration time has been extended to 4:00 pm today. So make sure that you register as soon as possible. 

The slots shall be emailed to all the registered students immediately after the registration process gets over. So, make sure you check your mail for the slot.

Also, the first years who are having NCC can come at 9:00pm at the CIC lab to take the test.

Here is the link for those who haven't received the mail yet.

Ahoy everyone! We hope everyone is eagerly waiting for the much sought after Winter Workshop. In order to attend the workshop, the aspirants must take the winter workshop test, which will have mental aptitude/logical questions, some questions on autonomous robotics (for the autonomous workshop) and some on coding (for the image processing workshop). This test is compulsory for attending the workshop. It is a non-qualifying test, implying that the aspirant will be able to attend the workshop irrespective of the score on the test.

There will be a few questions from the upcoming KRAIG 301 related to Image Processing. Thus, you are highly encouraged to attend the same. 

You can visit our website www.robotix.in for more information.

The tentative date for the test: 28th October 2018.

Here's the component list for the Hardware Hackathon for Line Following Robot to be held on 8/9th October. Do get the components at the earliest from Bots and chips (Prem Bazaar) or Chaudhary(Tech M)

1. IC7805 Voltage Regulator - 1
2. L293D Motor Driver - 1
3. IR Module - 2
4. 200rpm DC Motor - 2
5. Battery 9v-12v - 1
6. PCB - 1
7. Chasis - 1
8. Castor wheel - 1
9. Wheels - 2
10. Battery connector - 1
11. Solder iron - 1
12. Solder wire - 1
13. IC Bed for L293D - 1
14. Jumpers (male to female) - 6
15. 2 Pin relimate - 3

Hey, 1st and 2nd years!

Technology Robotix Society conducts an IEEE certified Winter Workshop every year for 1st and 2nd years interested in learning more advanced concepts of robotics, namely Autonomous Robotics and Image Processing. The workshop is conducted in two phases so that students who are attending the EAA camps in the first week of December can attend the second phase. Those who are interested in both autonomous robotics and image processing can attend both the phases.

Attendance in KRAIG classes is not compulsory to attend the Winter Workshop but is recommended.

We are releasing the tentative dates of the workshop so that the interested students may book their tickets in advance.

Phase 1: 30th November to 6th December
Phase 2: 8th December to 14th December

The Fresher's RoboSoccer got a great response. Around 30 teams had participated in the competition. We got to see a variety of bots having different designs and some even had mechanisms for shooting. Initially League matches were played which were followed by Knockout matches. Here are the winners for today's event-

Winner - Team Enigma (team ID 15)
Ashish Gokarnkar
Parth Paradkar
Alok Kumar 

1st Runner Up - Team Jugaadoos (team ID 17)
Akshit Gupta
Anirudh Gupta
Adarsh Soni

2nd Runner Up - Team Mutants (team ID 5)
Abhay Shukla
Anmol Harsh
Roshan Prabhakar

Technology Robotix Society Congratulates all the winning teams.

India’s policy think tank NITI Aayog (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NITI_Aayog andhttp://www.niti.gov.in/) is organizing MoveHack 2018, a global mobility hackathon to crowdsource solutions aimed at the future of mobility in India. Envisaged to be one of the largest hackathons globally, MoveHack is focused on 10 themes and structured over three legs: online, followed by Singapore leg, and the finals in New Delhi. MoveHack aims to bring about innovative, dynamic and scalable solutions to problems pertaining to mobility. The hackathon has a two-pronged campaign approach: (a) “Just Code It”: aimed at solutions through innovations in technology/product/software and data analysis, and (b) “Just Solve It”: innovative business ideas or sustainable solutions to transform mobility infrastructure through technology. Move Hack is open to individuals of all nationalities, making it a truly global hackathon. Registrations are open at https://www.movehack.gov.in. The top 30 teams from the online submissions will travel to Delhi to participate in the Final Round to be held in New Delhi on 5 and 6 Sep 2018. The winners will be announced during the Move Summit 2018, which is also organized by NITI Aayog on 7 and 8 Sep 2018 in New Delhi (http://movesummit.in/) and is being inaugurated by the Hon’ble Prime Minister of India. Awards for the hackathon include recognizing top 10 winners, with a total prize of more than Rs. 2 crores.

#Robotics, Autonomous Vehicles and Deep Learning conference 2018 which is going to be organized during September 10-11, 2018 in Singapore. Our Organization is very much delighted to invite you and  your Lab or department. Smart Robotic Conference 2018 is offering a wide range of benefits to promote and expose your research and services to the large number of audience and also if you want you can collaborate with us.

As the hardest problems of technology can only be solved by the open collaboration of world-wide scientific community. In order to make conference successful, participation from great organization like yours is very much required and we are expecting a large number of participants from your side for our conference.

For event details please log into: http://robotics.conferenceseries.com/

By collaborating with us you can avail the following benefits:
•         Display of logos on all event paraphernalia and areas around the event space as required.
•         Access to our attendees & delegates
•         Collaborators will get 25% discount on Conference registrations. 
•         Special Group discount to your members to attend the Smart Robotic Congress 2018
•         Opportunity to organize a workshop at any one of our events.
•         Registered Organizations logo will be displayed in the respective conference and supporting journal webpage with a statement "supported by"
•         Registered Organization for exhibition can organize a small symposium/exhibit a stall with complimentary registration pass at the event
•        You may avail one Free Conference pass for the board of director/ higher management from associated organization.

Events in smart robotics congress 2018:
•         Speaker slots for keynote talk and plenary talk for doctorates, professors, post-doctoral fellows and young research forum.
•        Workshops/Symposium platform for Doctorates and Professors.
•        Exhibitor booths for Robot Industries.
•       Poster presentation for students.

Thanks and Regards
Sincerely
Jack kallis
Conference Manager
Smart Robotics Congress 2018
47 Churchfield Road, London, W3 6AY, UK
Toll Free: USA: 1 (800) 216 6499 | UK: 44-800-098-8455 | Tokyo:  81-345780247

“However difficult life may seem, there is always something you can do and succeed at. All what matters is just that you don’t give up.”
Stephen Hawking

A living embodiment of countless extraordinary traits. The Genius of the twenty first century, left us today. Dedicating his whole life to answering the biggest question humankind could impose on itself - “Where did it all begin?” and putting together the greatest theory of all times in the field - “The Big Bang theory”, he effortlessly outsmarted us all. Without a hint of pride, he made groundbreaking progress in the fields of his work. He gave us - The Brief History of Time and was most probably working on some super-intelligent theory to reveal many secrets when he finally departed to find the eternal truth behind it all.
May his soul rest in peace.

A robot that is capable of changing it's interaxial distance to traverse ground that diverges, converges and turns. Sounds exciting, doesn't it? And now we present an event that provides a platform to do just that. 
To make your job easier, we've made tutorials and DIYs which will give you a head start. So dive right in.

Event doc: https://2018.robotix.in/event/poles-apart/
Event tutorial:https://2018.robotix.in/tutorial/event/poles-apart/
Event DIY: https://2018.robotix.in/img/event/poles-apart/polesapart.png
Video Tutorial : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FE2qt6iu2pA

Attention First and Second Years!
This is the Group division of the Phase-2 workshop. Please reach the given venue by 2pm on December 9th, 2017. 
Autonomous Group-1: F244, Main building
Autonomous Group-2: F236, Main building
IP: F235, Main building.

All the people attending the IP workshop try to dual boot your laptops with Ubuntu 16.04 before coming to save essential time and efforts.
Also, everyone kindly bring a flash drive for both autonomous and IP workshops.

Technology Robotix Society looks forward to providing the best learning experience. Good luck!

message:
As part of our motive to spread the culture of robotics all over the country, Technology Robotix Society recently conducted a robotics workshop at Bennett University, Noida. It was a great learning experience for both us and the students there. Read all about it here:
https://www.robotix.in/blog/noida-workshop-2017/

message:
After a memorable two and half days, Robotix 2017 was successfully concluded. Technology Robotix Society thanks all participants for their enthusiasm which was vital to make the fest such a huge event.

A special congratulation to all the winners of the three events : 

Bomb Disposal:
1st Prize: Vishwadeep Paul, Abdul Ali Adil Khan (CSIT, Durg)
2nd Prize: Sonu Gupta, Sidhant Gupta, Sourav Payra, Avishek Kumar Banka (Academy of Technology, West Bengal)
3rd Prize: Aman Tripathi, Rajat Kumar (Institute of Engineering and Rural Technology, Allahabad)
Best Freshers: Utkarsh Sharma, Mihir Sampat, Raj Tulshan, Divesh Goyal (IIT Kharagpur)
Best Mech Design: Raj Agarwal, Shreshth Tuli, Abhinav Kalra (IIT Delhi)

B.R.I.C.K.S.:
1st Prize: Naman Sharma, Balwant Singh Shekhawat, Abhishek Thamman, Rakshit Shukla (IIT BHU)
2nd Prize: Praveen Nyati, Ashwin Nehete, Shourya Kumar, Smriti Tiwari (IIT Kharagpur)
3rd Prize: Prabin Rath, Ateet Roy, Ankit Behera, Smruti Subudhi (NIT Rourkela)
Best Freshers: Palak Harwani, Harsh Maheshwari, Prerit Jain, Rohit Ner (IIT Kharagpur)
Best Embedded Design: Prince Agarwal, Abhinav Trivedi, Vishal Rana (NIT Patna)

Conquest:
1st Prize: Suraj Goel, Snigdha Dalvi, Prakhar Agrawal, Saurabh Gupta (IIT Delhi)
2nd Prize: Khayati Mittal, Samikshya Chand, Mayank Garg, Parth Shyara (IIT BHU)
3rd Prize: Harshit Goel, Abhay Saxena, Mayuna Gupta, Vivek Singal (IIT Delhi)
Best Freshers: Rahul Kumar, Sangam, G Rahul Kranti Kiran, Rajesh Prajapati (IIT Kharagpur)
Best Algorithm: Diptarghya Santra (NIT Rourkela)

"For once you have tasted flight you will walk the earth with your eyes turned skywards, for there you have been and there you will long to return. "
Embarking on a journey of thrill and exploration, Aerial Robotics Kharagpur and Swarm, IIT Kharagpur invite all first and second year robotics enthusiasts to join them in the Introductory Seminar.
February 23rd | Kalidas Auditorium | 6 PM

Fill out the form here to register yourself: https://quadrotor-iitkgp.github.io/recruit and tinyurl.com/SwarmSelections2017
